column1: Caffe latte (or simply latte) ( or ) is a coffee drink made with espresso and steamed milk. The word comes from the Italian caffè e latte [kafˌfɛ e lˈlatte]
column2: caffelatte [kaffeˈlatte] or caffellatte [kaffelˈlatte]
column3: which means "coffee & milk". The word is also sometimes spelled latté or lattè in English with different kinds of accent marks
column4: which can be a hyperforeignism or a deliberate attempt to indicate that the word is not pronounced according to the rules of English orthography.

column1: == Spelling variations ==
Coffee menus worldwide use a number of spelling variations for words to indicate coffee and milk
column2: often using incorrect accents or a combination of French and Italian terms. Italian is caffellatte (the standard form; caffelatte is a Northern Italian variation)
column3: contracted from caffè latte (with a grave accent over the e)
column4: while French is café au lait (with an acute accent); Spanish is café con leche and Portuguese is café com leite. Variants such as café latte
column5: café latté and café lattè are commonly seen in English. A slang name for a caffè latte is a 'lartay'

column8: impolite and disrespectful to Italian culture.

column1: == Iced latte ==
In the United States
column2: an iced latte is usually espresso and chilled milk poured over ice. Unlike a hot latte
column3: it does not usually contain steamed milk or foam. Iced lattes often have sugar or flavoring syrups added
column4: though purists prefer them to consist simply of coffee and milk; they are always served blended with ice. The espresso can be pre-chilled (sometimes as a mixture of espresso and milk) or frozen in advance to avoid warming up the drink.

column1: == Caffè latte vs. latte macchiato ==

column1: == Politics ==
Calling people "latte drinkers" pejoratively has become a common political attack in some Western cultures. The popularity of espresso drinking in large cities
column2: especially among more affluent urban populations
column3: has caused some to consider it elitist behavior. In the United States
column4: conservative political commentators have been known to call their opponents "latte-drinking liberal elites." In Canadian politics
column5: latte drinking is used to portray people as out-of-touch intellectuals and the antithesis of the Tim Hortons coffee drinker that is considered representative of an ordinary Canadian. In Scandinavian politics
column6: the term "the caffè latte segment" is used to describe elitist voters.According to a 2018 study
column7: 16% of liberals in the United States prefer lattes
column8: whereas 9% of conservatives and 11% of moderates do. The overwhelming majority of people
column11: express a preference for regular brewed coffee.
